MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - EU Funding.

Qst.askee: Minister for Tourism, Sport and Recreation
Qst.Quest: the progress, if any, on the urban and rural development monitoring committee established to monitor Structural Funds in Ireland.

Qst.askee: Minister for Tourism, Sport and Recreation
Qst.Quest: if he will report on the progress on the local development programme since the formation of the Government.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Tourism, Sport and Recreation (Mr. Flood)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 379 and 383 together.

The Operational Programme for Local Urban and Rural Development 1994-9 was designed to bring about social and economic development at a local level, to involve and enable local communities to be involved in that development in a formal way and to achieve physical improvements to the environment.

MainHeading.P: It comprises three main integrated sub-programmes on local enterprise which is managed by the Department of Enterprise, Trade and Employment, integrated development of designated disadvantaged and other areas, and urban and village renewal which is managed by the Department of the Environment and Local Government. Technical assistance is provided for under the fourth sub-programme. Total funding under the programme as at 31 December 1998 is £339 million (EUR 437m). Expenditure under the OP to date has been progressing steadily, as follows: 1994 – £14 million (EUR 18m); 1995 – £56 million (EUR 68m); 1996 – £61 million (EUR 79m); 1997 – £76 million (EUR 102m); 1998 – £79 million (EUR 103m) (estimate) and currently totals £286 million (EUR 370m). Each of the sub-programmes is confident that all available funds will be committed and spent within programme deadlines.
My Department has particular responsibility for sub-programme 2 – integrated development of designated disadvantaged and other areas which is administered by ADM Ltd.

The monitoring committee for the operational programme for local urban and rural development 1994-9 has met on ten occasions since the operational programme was agreed. The last meeting was held on 7 October 1998. The next meeting is due to take place on 31 March 1999 and one of the main documents for that meeting will be the 1998 annual report. I will arrange to have a copy of this report forwarded to the Deputy following its adoption.

Qst.askee: Minister for Tourism, Sport and Recreation
Qst.Quest: the progress, if any, on the community initiatives monitoring committee established to monitor Structural Funds in Ireland.

Qst.askee: Minister for Tourism, Sport and Recreation
Qst.Quest: the progress, if any, on the urban initiative monitoring committee established to monitor Structural Funds in Ireland.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Tourism, Sport and Recreation (Mr. Flood)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 380 and 381 together.

As there is no community initiatives monitoring committee as such, I take it that the Deputy's interest, in this instance, is the only community initiative for which my Department has lead responsibility, i.e. the community initiative known as the operational programme for URBAN 1996-9.

MainHeading.P: The Operational Programme for URBAN is designed to tackle urban issues in an integrated way, supporting business creation, improving infrastructure and the physical environment, providing customised training, and actions for equality of opportunity and social amenities, in line with the strategic action plans drawn up for each of the three areas. Total funding available under the URBAN OP is some £22.1 million (EUR 28.2 million). The OP makes funding available across a number of sub-programmes, one for each of the three selected areas in Ireland; the north Dublin area of Ballymun-Finglas-Darndale (sub-programme 1 – £10.4 million/EUR 13.3 million), west Tallaght-Clondalkin in south-west Dublin (sub-programme 2 – £5.4 million/EUR 6.9 million) and the northside of Cork city (sub-programme 3 – £5.4 million/EUR 6.9 million), sub-programme 4 funds technical assistance activities (£0.9million/EUR 1.1 million).

A total of £15.8 million (EUR 20.1 million) or 72 per cent of total available funding has been committed as of 31 December 1998. Actual expenditure under the OP to 31 December 1998 was some £6 million (EUR 7.7 million) or 27 per cent of the overall budget. Given the bottom-up nature of the programme, this initial low level of spend was to be expected particularly given the time needed to have the new collaborative structures put in place and the volume and scale of the community infrastructural projects being supported. However, the three steering groups under the OP expect a sharp increase in expenditure in 1999 and are confident of their ability to commit and spend all remaining funds within programme deadlines.

The monitoring committee for URBAN OP has met on five occasions since the OP was agreed. The next meeting is due to take place on 18 February 1999. One of the main documents for that meeting is the 1998 annual report. I will arrange to have a copy of this report forwarded to the Deputy following its adoption.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Local Government Reform.

Qst.askee: Minister for Tourism, Sport and Recreation
Qst.Quest: his views on the future policy implications for local development in Ireland having regard to the development of local governance, rural development and equality issues.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Tourism, Sport and Recreation (Mr. Flood)
Speaker.P: The Government is committed to the restoration of real power and decision-making at local level, as part of its major programme of local government reform. To this end, it established an inter-Departmental task force for the integration of local government and local development systems last year, of which I was a member.

The task force produced a report containing recommendations which are laying the groundwork for a closer working relationship between the local government and local development sectors and also for a more integrated framework for the development and delivery of public services at city-county level. These recommendations were endorsed by the Government, which include, inter alia, the replacement of city-county strategy groups by more comprehensive city-county development boards in January 2000.

MainHeading.P: The development boards will comprise representatives of local government; State agencies at local level, local development agencies and the social partners, including the community and vol untary sector. Together, they will draw up city-county strategies on economic, social and cultural development which will form the policy framework for all relevant agencies operating locally. The new, integrated system will mean more focused and inclusive local governance, with real and meaningful local input.

As regards rural development in particular, the Department of Agriculture and Food is currently preparing a White Paper on the subject, which will set out Government policy in this area for the medium to long-term. It is expected that the White Paper will be published in the next few months. I am advised that, in preparing the White Paper, regard will be had to the work of rural partnerships and community groups, funded under sub-programme 2 of the operational programme for local, urban and rural development (LURD).

With regard to equality issues, which are primarily the responsibility of the Department of Justice, Equality and Law Reform, ADM Ltd., manages, on an agency basis, the equal opportunities childcare programme on behalf of that Department, which is focused on areas of disadvantage. The partnerships have, as a result, also been involved in the development and implementation of the programme as a whole.

In framing proposals for a future local development programme, under the national development plan, 2000-6, my Department will take full account of the experience and results of the current operational programme and of the role of other Departments and statutory agencies in the local development field.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Tourism Training.

Qst.askee: Minister for Tourism, Sport and Recreation
Qst.Quest: the consideration he has given to putting in place an appropriate system to ensure all tourist operators and tourist guides have the required knowledge and other supports; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism, Sport and Recreation (Dr. McDaid)
Speaker.P: CERT, the State tourism training agency, provides a comprehensive tour guide training programme for persons wishing to become national tour guides. This programme is certified by the National Tourism Certification Board and is a pre-requisite for approval as a national tour guide. CERT also provides tour guide training for Dublin city guides, driver guides and local guides throughout the country. In addition, when requested, CERT provides customised training programmes for incoming tour operators.

MainHeading.P: Development work has recently commenced on a travel agency programme which would facilitate first level employment in travel agencies. Discussions between CERT and the Irish Travel Agencies Association are continuing on the programme and it will be implemented at craft level in the institutes of technology when approved.

Qst.askee: Minister for Tourism, Sport and Recreation
Qst.Quest: the likely biggest economic contributor category of tourist to Ireland in 1999; the estimated spend per head; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism, Sport and Recreation (Dr. McDaid)
Speaker.P: I am informed by Bord Fáilte that in 1997, the latest year for which final expenditure data is available, tourists from Britain, Ireland's biggest single market, spent £683 million in the Irish economy which at 43 per cent is close to half of the total overseas tourist spend. However, in terms of per capita spend, the American tourist, spending an average of £448 per head while holidaying in Ireland was the biggest spender in 1997. Bórd Fáilte are forecasting growth of 11 per cent for the British market and 9 per cent for the US market this year.

Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: if he has addressed the issue of grant docking of ESF grants with the EU Social Fund; if his attention has been drawn to the concern relating to the operation of these grants with many students; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the system of docking of maintenance grants in some courses at third level; his views on whether the fact that this system applies to only some third level students is grossly unfair; and the amount of maintenance grant payments students are losing through this inequitable system.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 390 and 419 together.

The objective of the middle level technician and higher technical-business skills programme is to enhance industrial competitiveness and growth by providing initial third level education and training to meet the technical and higher level manpower needs of the economy and the regulations emphasise the extent to which training conditions mirror the reality of the work environment, thereby preparing trainees for the workplace.

The regulations governing the middle level technician and higher technical-business skills programme state that: “Trainees on the programmes will be subject to normal industrial disciplines during training regarding time keeping, absenteeism etc., and the Institute Authorities will be required to reflect these factors in the payment of allowances. Trainees may be allowed sick leave without reduction in the level of grant for a maximum of 15 days per academic year. All such absences must be notified to the Institute Authorities in writing.” Normal industrial discipline refers to the normal conditions which exist in the workplace, for example notifying absences due to illness in writing to the college authorities. My Department does not have any details in relation to the amount of maintenance grants payments students are losing under this provision of the ESF maintenance grants scheme and it had not been brought to my attention that this provision is causing concern to many students.

The higher education grants scheme and the vocational education committees' scholarship scheme allow for the payments of grants in three equal instalments. These grants are paid on the basis of the student continuing to be a registered student at college rather than a roll call taken on a daily basis which is the system which operates on ESF aided courses in the institutes of technology.

The method of payment of grants under the various student support schemes is one of the issues which will be addressed in the context of the review of the administration of the third level student support schemes which is being undertaken by officials of my Department and the Department of Social, Community and Family Affairs.

Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: his views on whether it is acceptable for a remedial teacher to be expected to deal adequately with 70 children; and the plans, if any, he has to provide a resource teacher in schools located in growing areas such as north County Dublin, particularly in relation to Pope John Paul II national school, Malahide, County Dublin (details supplied).

Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the urgent need for a resource teacher in Pope John Paul II national school, Malahide, County Dublin, in view of the fact the remedial teacher is dealing with 70 children and cannot give the kind of time that is needed for some children.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 391 and 394 together.

I am aware that the school in question has applied to my Department for a resource teacher. I can assure the Deputy that I would not regard it as reasonable to expect a remedial teacher to deal adequately with 70 children.

I recently announced a major new initiative in the special education area under which all children assessed as having special educational needs will be entitled to an automatic response to those needs. The level and nature of the response in each case will depend on the assessed needs of the child or group of children involved. The response may take the form of resource teacher support or child care support, or both, depending on the number of children involved and the nature of their needs.

My Department's inspectorate is currently investigating the special education needs of pupils attending Pope John Paul II national school, including those requiring a remedial service. A decision on the special support services required by the school will be based on the inspectorate's findings.

I understand that the investigation is almost complete and that the inspector's report is expected shortly. Once the report is received, my Department will proceed with the allocation of the appropriate resources as speedily as possible.

Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: if he will make a statement on the fact that some of the primary school students who require the most help are those who get the least help due to the lack of resource and remedial teachers nationally; and if he will ensure that with the large investments that are being made in the third level sector, additional resources will be made available in the primary school sector to allow a resource and a remedial teacher to be provided in every school.

Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: when a remedial teacher will be posted to Tavneena national school, Charlestown, County Mayo.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 392 and 411 together.
Since my appointment as Minister for Education and Science, I have attached a clear priority to the development of support services for children with special educational needs in the primary system.

I consider that my commitment in this regard is clearly demonstrated by my decision to extend the remedial teacher service to every primary school in the country with effect from September next. A total of 225 additional teacher posts are being made available to support this development and also to facilitate the extension of the home-school-community liaison scheme to all primary schools which are designated as disadvantaged.
As a result of the new resources being provided by this Government, Tavneena national school will be among the schools which will receive a remedial service from September next.

I also recently announced a major new initiative under which all children assessed as having special education needs arising from a disability will henceforth be entitled to an automatic response to those needs. The response may take the form of resource teacher support or child care support, or both, depending on the needs of each individual child. Already under this new initiative, my Department has allocated an additional 33 resource teacher posts and 156 child care assistant posts to support special needs children in the primary system.

I am satisfied that the measures which I have taken will ensure that all primary school children who require remedial or resource teacher support will receive the necessary assistance to enable them to gain maximum benefit from their participation in the education system.

Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: the reason the necessary resources were not made available to Kinsealy national school, County Dublin, to deal with a person (details supplied) to ensure she receives an adequate education in view of her physical disability.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I understand that a member of my Department's inspectorate has visited Kinsealy national school to determine the precise supports required to cater for the needs of the child in question.
The inspector's report is expected in my Department this week and I can assure the Deputy that any recommendations contained in that report will be acted upon as speedily as possible.

Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the fact that St. Killian's senior national school, Kingswood, Dublin 24 has applied for basic facilities for 12 years; the reason this large school in an expanding area does not have essential accommodation including a general purposes area for physical education classes, remedial, medical and library rooms, wheelchair toilet facilities, an adequate principal's office, a parents' room and an equipment storage room; the plans, if any, he has to provide these facilities; the timescale in this regard; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I am aware that the management of St. Killian's senior national school, Kingswood, has recently renewed its application for grant assistance for the provision of a general purpose room, and ancillary accommodation.

The school was built in the late 1980s and was provided with the standard facilities at that time. However, due to the severe financial difficulties during that period, general purpose rooms were excluded and priority had to be given to the provision of essential classroom accommodation.

My Department is currently re-examining the accommodation requirements of St. Killian's school in the light of the recent application. When this work has been completed, my Department will be in further contact with the school management. At this stage, I am not in a position to give a commitment in respect of a major project at the school.

Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: when work will commence on the new community school at Ballyshannon, County Donegal; and if all issues related to planning and traffic management have been resolved.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: Architectural design of the new community school project at Ballyshannon, County Donegal, has been completed and tenders are being sought at present. Once the tendering process has been completed it is intended that this project will proceed to construction.

Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: the progress, if any, made in the provision of an all Irish second level school in the Baldoyle area of County Dublin in view of the fact that Deputy Owen understands Scoil Neasan has made an application for such a school; and if any other all Irish primary or secondary schools are being provided currently in the Dublin area.

Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: if it is still his intention to provide an all Irish secondary school in the north-east Dublin area before the start of the 1999 school year having regard to an application by An Fochoiste Meánoideachais; if arrangements are being put in place to facilitate this year's primary school leavers; if his attention has been drawn to the anger of parents who have to travel long distances to alternative schools with their children; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr, Martin)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 397 and 408 together.

The position is that an application was received in my Department from a local group, An Fochoiste Meánoideachais and City of Dublin Vocational Education Committee, regarding the provision of an all-Irish second level school in north-east Dublin. The proposed location of the school was a site adjacent to Scoil Neasáin in Artane.

An examination of the need for such facility was carried out by the planning section of my Department. The result indicated a significant level of demand arising from increased all-Irish provision at primary school level in this area in recent years. An assessment carried out by the technical staff of my Department revealed that, at 1.2 acres, the proposed site adjacent to Scoil Neasáin would be totally inadequate as a location for a permanent school building.

I accept that some pupils in north-east Dublin may experience inconvenience in terms of distance to an existing all-Irish second level school. My Department will continue to work with An Fochoiste Meánoideachais and City of Dublin Vocational Education Committee to develop an appropriate response at the earliest possible date.
There are no other applications in my Department at present for the provision of additional all-Irish primary or second level schools in the Dublin area.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Schools Building Projects.

Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: if the application in respect of St. Matthew's national school, Cranfield Place, Sandymount, Dublin 4, has been submitted for approval to proceed to architectural planning; if building work will commence during the summer months when the school is closed; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The Deputy will be pleased to hear that a project to provide additional accommodation at St. Matthew's national school, Cranfield Place, has recently been approved to proceed to architectural planning.

MainHeading.P: At this early stage in the planning process, it is not possible to give a realistic timescale for work commencing on site.

Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: if he will have arrangements made for grant assistance or financial help for the urgent private remedial teaching of a person (details supplied) in County Mayo whose school does not offer this service until September.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I understand that the child in question has recently been assessed and that recommendations have been made in the assessment report regarding the child's special educational needs.

My Department has asked the school concerned to forward a copy of the assessment report so that arrangements can be made to put any necessary support services in place. This report is currently awaited.

Qst.hpid: Mr. M. Higgins Mr. M. Higgins
Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: if he will meet a deputation from County Galway VEC to discuss the completion of phase three of the Petersburg outdoor education centre.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I am considering a request to meet a delegation from County Galway Vocational Education Committee regarding the above matter. My Department is currently in contact with the VEC chief executive officer regarding the development work in Petersburg outdoor education centre.

Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: if qualified Montessori teachers (details supplied) will be eligible for substitute and permanent posts in primary schools from September 1999; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The Montessori teachers referred to by the Deputy are recognised by my Department to teach in certain special schools for the mentally handicapped, the emotionally disturbed and the hearing impaired. In addition these teachers are also recognised as fully qualified for substitute teaching purposes in mainstream primary schools. However, they are not eligible for permanent positions in mainstream primary schools.

Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: the special arrangements persons (details supplied) in County Kildare can expect for their children sitting exams in view of their learning difficulties.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: My Department provides a range of special arrangements for students with specific learning difficulties at the certificate examinations. Applications for special arrangements on the grounds of a specific learning difficulty are made by the authorities of the school concerned and are considered individually on the basis of evidence submitted, including psychological reports. Applications are usually made about a year before the actual examination in question.

After full consideration is given to an application the school is notified of the outcome and a candidate who is not satisfied with the arrangements proposed by the Department has access to a special arrangements appeals committee. The process, which I have outlined above, can of course apply to the students referred to by the Deputy should they apply for special arrangements.

Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, he has to provide computers for children suffering from dyslexia in view of the fact that his Department's psychologists are recommending this means of education for sufferers.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: A special fund of £250,000 has been allocated under Schools IT 2000 to provide assistance to schools in catering for the ICT needs of individual special needs pupils, including those with specific learning disability such as dyslexia.

Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: if he will give details of the schools in Dublin that have availed of the IT 2000 programme; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: All recognised primary schools and all post-primary schools in the free education scheme, in Dublin and throughout the country, have benefited from the Schools IT 2000 programme. All schools have received technology grants for the purchase of multimedia computers under the Technology Integration Initiative and a total of 2,290 teachers at first and second level in the Dublin area availed of ICT training programmes, approved by the National Centre for Technology in Education and my Department in 1998. Some 118 Dublin primary and post-primary schools have recently applied for inclusion in the schools integration project, SIP, a national initiative on innovative ICT development in schools and a further component of Schools IT 2000. I expect to announce the selected SIP schools in the very near future.

Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, he has to implement dual enrolment for children with mental disability who are currently in mainstream education which would allow them to attend a special school for one or two days a week; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I can assure the Deputy that I am anxious to support any reasonable measure which will facilitate children with special education needs in gaining the maximum possible benefit from the education system. I fully appreciate the benefits which can accrue to some special needs children by being able to participate in a mainstream primary schools while at the same time having a degree of access to the more intensive support services available in the special school system.

I have requested my Department to examine the merits of the dual enrolment issue and how it might be facilitated in practice. The Deputy will appreciate that the introduction of such an arrangement would have potential resource and other implications which will require careful consideration. All of these issues will be examined.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Psychological Services.

Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: the number of new appointments to be made to the primary school psychological service; when these appointments will be completed; if it will be possible for all schools in County Wexford to access this service; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I am aware that there are many primary schools in the country, including all the primary schools in County Wexford, which do not yet have access to my Department's psychological service. One of my key priorities as Minister is the establishment of a national educational psychological service, to be available to all schools at both levels. On 15 September last, I launched and endorsed the report of the planning group, which has prepared recommendations for me on how a national educational psychological service may best be introduced. Financial provision has now been made for the first two years of a five-year implementation phase. At the end of the five-year period, it is envisaged that every school in the country will have access to a schools psychological service.

MainHeading.P: The Deputy will be aware that psychological services to primary schools are much enhanced in the current school year with the appointment in 1998 of 15 psychologists specifically for that sector in a development project involving my Department's psychological service and Mary Immaculate College of Education.

Subject to the approval of Government, implementation of the report will begin shortly, with the recruitment of 25 additional psychologists, who should take up their appointments during the school year 1999-2000. It is intended that the psychological service will be an integrated service for the primary and second level sectors and, from now on, newly recruited psychologists will be expected to work in both sectors. My Department is currently carrying out a detailed analysis of the needs and resources available in all parts of the country, in order to set priorities for the expansion of the national educational psychological service.

Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: if funding has been agreed by his Department for the provision of security fencing on the perimeter of St. Lawrence O'Toole's primary CBS school, Seville Place, Dublin 1.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: An application has been received from the management of St. Laurence O'Toole's senior national school for the provision of a security fence. The documentation necessary for a planning application has been forwarded to the school.

Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: if, further to Parliamentary Question No. 190 of 5 November 1998 and Parliamentary Question No. 371 of 1 December 1998, his Department will investigate the delay in the psychological service making contact with a person (details supplied) in County Kilkenny as promised in these replies; if his Department will set a date for the assessment and indicate the way in which this person can be assisted or placed in full-time employment or training; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: My Department recognises the needs of the person mentioned. It was intended that a member of the psychological service would contact him before the end of last December. Due to unforeseen circumstances, the contact had to be postponed. I understand that an appointment is being offered this week.

Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: if his Department has considered the proposal for a co-educational school for Thomastown, County Kilkenny, resulting in the amalgamation of the two existing schools; if he will give a positive response to the boards of management who have made a formal application to his Department regarding the proposal; the way in which the proposal can be funded and the way in which the boards of management should proceed; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: As outlined in my response to Questions Nos. 984 and 988 on 27 January 1999 an application from the boards of management for an amalgamation of the two primary schools in Thomastown, County Kilkenny, is presently under active consideration in the planning section of my Department. When the examination has been completed, contact will be made with the boards of management regarding the details.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Psychological Services.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: the number of children at primary and second levels who received a psychological assessment from the psychological service in each of the past three years; the number of psychologists at each level in each of the past three years; and the targeted level of staff and activity in each of the years 1999 and 2000.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: Casework statistics provided by my Department's psychological service for the past three school years are set out in tabular form below for the Deputy's information. Until the school year 1997-98, only the number of referrals received was recorded, without further analysis. Since that time, data on the numbers of assessments, full and partial, have also been collected.

MainHeading.P: The numbers of psychologists do not include psychologists in promotional posts who are not directly engaged in work in schools, two in 1995-96 and 1996-97 and three in 1997-98. Eight of the post-primary psychologists were promoted to the grade of senior during the school year 1997-98. Because of their new supervisory responsibilities, they consequently devoted somewhat less of their time to casework than had previously been the case.

The service to primary schools is much enhanced in the current school year with the appointment in 1998 of 15 psychologists specifically for that sector in a development project involving my Department's psychological service and Mary Immaculate College of Education, Limerick.

Subject to the approval of Government, implementation of the report of the planning group for the national educational psychological service will begin shortly. It is envisaged that 25 additional psychologists will be recruited during each of the years 1999 and 2000. These psychologists should begin to take up their appointments during the school year 1999-2000. My Department is currently carrying out a detailed analysis of the needs and resources available in all parts of the country, in order to set priorities for the expansion of the National Educational Psychological Service.

Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: if the decision made on an educational grant for a person (details supplied) in County Roscommon will be rescinded in view of the fact that her mother's income from April 1997 to September 1997 is annualised when in fact she was not in receipt of the widow's pension until September 1997; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: In accordance with the change of circumstances clause of the European Social Fund-aided maintenance grant scheme, a candidate's eligibility for grant aid may be reassessed in the event of a change in reckonable income which is likely to be permanent. This change in circumstances may be positive or negative and in either situation the revised income is annualised and the grant entitlement assessed thereon. My officials have checked the method of assessment in this case with Roscommon VEC and I understand that the correct procedure was followed in this case.

Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: if he will make a special concession to ensure that Asdee national school, Listowel, County Kerry, will return its present staffing level of four teachers; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The staffing of national schools for a particular year is determined by the enrolment of the school on 30 September of the previous year. The enrolment of Asdee national school on 30 September 1999 was 85 pupils. Under the existing staffing schedule, this is insufficient for the retention of the fourth teaching post at the school. However, I should point out to the Deputy that I have not as yet made final decisions regarding the staffing allocations which will apply in primary schools in the 1999-2000 school year. When decisions have been taken in this matter, my officials will examine the position of Asdee national school and correspond with the school's managerial authorities in the matter.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Third Level Fees.

Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: if, further to Parliamentary Question No. 170 of 28 January 1999, his attention has been drawn to the fact that the degree course previously followed by the person concerned was not grant aided and was not at an Irish university and, consequently, he may be eligible for lecture and maintenance fees in this instance at Trinity College; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: Under the terms of the third level student support schemes, maintenance grants are not payable to candidates who already hold an undergraduate degree and are pursuing a second undergraduate degree. Similarly tuition fees under the free fees initiative, are not payable in respect of a second period of college attendance on a course at the same level. These restrictions apply to every student who already holds a qualification at any level, irrespective of where that qualification was obtained.

As the student referred to by the Deputy already holds a degree from Leeds University, he is, therefore, ineligible for a higher education grant or to benefit under the free fees initiative in respect of the degree course he is currently pursuing at Trinity College Dublin.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: the steps, if any, he has taken to deal with the difficulties being experienced by student nurses undertaking the fourth year of their degree in nursing at the National University of Ireland, Galway; and if his attention has been drawn to the fact that these students are the only full-time undergraduated students in a State-funded college paying tuition fees.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: As the Deputy will be aware, the revised programme for basic pre-registration nurse education and training which was introduced in October 1994 is funded by the Department of Health and Children. Successful completion of the three year programme leads to a diploma in nursing studies and students are eligible to register with An Bord Altranais for employment as a nurse.

Furthermore, the Commission on Nursing has recommended that the future framework for the pre-registration education of nurses should be based on a four year degree programme and a forum, involving the third level institutions, the schools of nursing, health services providers and An Board Altranais is being established by the Minister for Health and Children to agree a strategy for the implementation of degree level pre-registration nursing education and training.

MainHeading.P: The position is that the one year full-time degree course leading to a Bachelor of Nursing which is offered by National University of Ireland, Galway, to students who have successfully completed the nursing registration-diploma programmes, has not been recognised for the purposes of the free fees initiative. In relation to the question of degree programmes, there are a number of part-time programmes which are provided on a self-financing basis. The course at National University of Galway is the only full-time degree course. I understand that the Minister for Health and Children is not in a position to provide funding for these courses which lead to optional post-registration qualification. As legal proceedings have been instituted in relation to the non-pay ment of fees for the course in question, I do not consider it appropriate for me to comment further on the matter.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: the way in which the £3 million fund to tackle disadvantage at third level and the £1.5 million to deal with the problem of non-completion of third level courses, announced in the budget, will be spent.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I have recently announced details of a £6.9 million two-year funding initiative to tackle educational disadvantage in the third level sector. Of this funding, £3 million is being specifically allocated to promote access to third level among students from disadvantaged backgrounds, including people with disabilities. A further £1.5 million is being provided to address the issue of non-completion of courses in institutes of technology. Details of the allocation of these additional resources will be announced in due course when I have fully considered how best to proceed in these areas.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: his views on the situation where students under the age of 23 on 1 January in their year of entry into college are assessed on their own plus their parents or guardians income regardless of their circumstances.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The provisions of the student support schemes require that parental income be taken into account, irrespective of the individual circumstances, in any case where a student applying for a maintenance grant is not a mature student, that is, any student who is under 23 years of age on 1 January of the year of entry to an approved course. I appreciate the difficulties that these provisions can give rise to in individual cases and I have asked my officials to examine the situation.

Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: the reason the terms of the higher education grants scheme have been amended in such a manner as to disallow payment of a grant in respect of a second period of attendance at the same level of an approved course; if his attention has been drawn to the fact that this change in regulations has had a negative effect on a small number of students including a person (details supplied) in County Cork; if he will review this application; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: Under the terms of the third level student support schemes, candidates who have previously pursued an undergraduate course approved for the purposes of the schemes shall not be eligible for grant assistance until they have completed an equivalent period of study at undergraduate level, irrespective of whether or not a grant was paid previously. As the student in question has already pursued year one of a diploma course and is now pursuing year one of a degree course she is ineligible for grant assistance for this year. She will, however, be eligible to apply for a grant for the remaining years of her course.

These provisions are designed to avoid the payment of grants to students who repeat year levels on different courses. However, I would point out to the Deputy that there is provision within the schemes for students who hold a national certificate or diploma to progress to degree level courses.

Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: the current situation regarding an application by Coppeen national school, County Cork, for grant aid for school and schoolyard improvements.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: My Department has asked the Office of Public Works in Cork to prepare tender specifications for improvement works at Coppeen national school. These specifications are currently being prepared and the school is aware of the position.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: if primary teachers have with drawn their services from the National Centre for Technology in Education; if so, the impact of this withdrawal on training and other programmes; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: Approximately half of the 600 primary tutors for the spring, 1999 ICT training programmes for teachers under Schools IT 2000 have withdrawn their services pending the outcome of discussions between my Department, the National Centre for Technology in Education – NCTE – and the INTO on tutor rates of pay. ICT training programmes are provided largely through the Education Centre Network and the withdrawal of tutor services is concentrated in some of the larger urban education centre areas. I understand that the discussions taking place between my Department, NCTE and the INTO on this matter are at an advanced stage of development and, accordingly, I expect that this matter will be resolved in the very near future.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.askee: Minister for Education and Science
Qst.Quest: if he will appoint a co-ordinator to support the process of whole school planning in schools; and the criteria being applied in the selection of a suitable candidate.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: School development planning guidelines for primary schools will be published shortly and issued to schools. Guidelines for second level schools will be published later in 1999. I intend to appoint two co-ordinators, one at each level, to assist all schools on a phased basis, but initially those serving disadvantaged areas, in the implementation of the school development planning process.
